meta.author: MedPhys Speed Quiz
meta.notes: Each question needs: id (unique), q (question text), a (correct answer ‚Äî MUST exactly match one choice), c (4 choices), s (section id), e (explanation shown after answering wrong). To add questions: just append to the section array. To add a section: add to 'sections' and create matching array in 'questions'.

srt.e: SRS demands sub-mm precision. Winston-Lutz verifies radiation and mechanical isocentre coincidence.
IAEA TRS-483 provides the framework for reference and relative dosimetry of small and non-standard fields.
If tumour motion exceeds 5 mm on 4D-CT, active management (gating, DIBH, compression) is required.
Without the flattening filter the beam has a peaked forward intensity, sharper penumbra, and lower out-of-field dose.
Small targets require fine calculation grids. 1 mm ideal for SRS; 2 mm acceptable for SBRT.
CI = prescription isodose volume / target volume. A value of 1.0 means perfect conformity.
SASQART 2025 defines SBRT as ‚â• 5 Gy per fraction in ‚â§ 5 fractions. SRS is single-fraction intracranial.
End-to-end tests the full clinical chain using an anthropomorphic phantom. Gold standard for SRT commissioning.
GI = V50%/Vprescription. Lower GI = steeper dose falloff = better sparing of surrounding tissue.
AAPM TG-101 provides comprehensive guidance for SBRT including tolerances, QA, and clinical protocols.
When field size < lateral electron range, charged particle equilibrium is lost, invalidating standard dosimetry.
PTW 60019 microDiamond has ~0.004 mm¬≥ sensitive volume ‚Äî ideal for small-field output factors per TRS-483.
PCI = (TV_PIV)¬≤/(TV √ó PIV). Unlike simple CI, it penalises both target miss and excessive irradiation.
Frameless SRS with thermoplastic masks + IGRT is now standard. SASQART: sole laser positioning no longer acceptable.
SBRT allows slightly larger tolerance than SRS (‚â§ 1 mm) due to larger PTV margins, but still tight.
CyberKnife uses orthogonal kV imaging to track fiducials or bony anatomy in real-time, correcting the robotic arm during delivery.
Leksell Gamma Knife uses ~192 Co-60 sources arranged in a hemisphere to converge on a stereotactic target.
RTOG 0236 established 54 Gy/3 fx for peripheral T1-T2 NSCLC. Central lesions require more conservative fractionation.
Internal Target Volume encompasses all CTV positions across the breathing cycle, typically defined from 4D-CT.
Patient holds breath at deep inspiration to immobilise the tumour and move heart away from the treatment field (e.g., left breast).
Volume receiving ‚â•12 Gy correlates with symptomatic radionecrosis risk. V12 < 10 cm¬≥ is generally considered safe.
Brainlab ExacTrac combines infrared surface tracking with stereoscopic kV X-ray imaging for 6DOF correction.
The detector-specific output correction factor converts readings in small clinical fields relative to the machine-specific reference field.
Single-fraction spine SBRT limits cord point max to ~14 Gy (0.03cc). Multi-fraction limits are proportionally higher.

srt.q: CALC: GI = V50%/V100%. If V50% = 30 cm¬≥ and V100% = 10 cm¬≥, GI = ?
srt.e: Gradient Index = 30/10 = 3.0. Lower is better ‚Äî indicates steeper dose falloff around the target.
Adaptive RT re-optimises plans based on daily anatomy (e.g., Ethos, MR-Linac), critical for abdominal SBRT where organs shift.
MR-Linac (e.g., Elekta Unity, ViewRay) provides continuous MR imaging during delivery ‚Äî superior soft tissue contrast without ionising radiation.
SRS often prescribes to a lower isodose line (50-80%) to achieve steep dose gradients and hot spots within the target.

srt.q: CALC: Paddick CI = (TV_PIV)¬≤/(TV √ó PIV). TV=5cc, PIV=6cc, TV_PIV=4.5cc. PCI=?
srt.e: PCI = (4.5)¬≤ / (5 √ó 6) = 20.25 / 30 = 0.675. Values closer to 1.0 indicate better conformity.

srt.a: Ablate limited mets, delay systemic Rx
c: Ablate limited mets, delay systemic Rx
srt.e: SBRT to 1-5 oligomets can achieve durable local control, potentially deferring or eliminating the need for systemic therapy.

qa.e: TG-142 daily output check. Exceeding this requires investigation before treating patients.
Monthly checks use a calibrated chamber. Tighter than daily because measurement is more rigorous.
TRS-398 absolute calibration target. The gold-standard reference that monthly and daily checks anchor to.
TG-142 replaced TG-40, covering daily/monthly/annual QA tolerances for modern linacs.
TG-119 provides benchmark plans and confidence limits for IMRT commissioning verification.
TG-106 covers beam data commissioning: scanning systems, detectors, measurement protocols.
TG-218 recommends 3%/3mm with ‚â• 95% pass as universal tolerance and 90% as action limit.
Equally-spaced MLC strips on EPID/film reveal systematic leaf position errors.
Accounts for radiation leaking through rounded MLC leaf ends. Measured via sweeping gap technique.
Tolerances and methodology for patient-specific IMRT/VMAT measurement-based verification.
kV CBCT isocenter must coincide with treatment isocenter within 1 mm for SRS.
Each leaf must position within 1 mm of planned. Checked with picket fence and log file analysis.
Strategies for effective physics review of treatment plans ‚Äî catching errors before delivery.
Machine Performance Check: automated daily QA verifying output, beam characteristics, and geometry.
SRS/SBRT laser alignment is tighter than conventional (¬± 2 mm).
Monthly kV/MV imaging-to-treatment isocenter coincidence must be within 2 mm for standard treatments.
Multiple gantry angles expose a film/EPID at isocentre. The spoke pattern reveals the radiation isocentre diameter.

qa.q: Log file analysis for VMAT verifies?
qa.e: Machine log files record real-time gantry, MLC, and MU data ‚Äî can be compared to planned parameters for delivery verification.
Full TRS-398/TG-51 calibration must agree within 1% of the stated output. This is the gold standard.
Elekta uses the QC-3 phantom with iViewGT EPID for daily constancy checks (output, flatness, symmetry).
The EPID panel captures transmitted fluence and compares it to predicted images for IMRT/VMAT QA.

qa.a: Cylindrical diode array for VMAT QA
c: Cylindrical diode array for VMAT QA
qa.e: Sun Nuclear ArcCHECK: 1386 diodes on a cylindrical surface for 3D composite dose verification of rotational plans.
Digital gantry readout must agree with actual angle within ¬±1¬∞ for daily checks.
Measured in the flattened region (80% of field width). Monthly tolerance typically ¬± 2%.
Ratio of dose at symmetric points about the central axis. Monthly tolerance typically ¬± 2-3%.
Monthly per TG-142 for standard use. Daily recommended when SRS/SRT patients are being treated.

qa.q: CALC: IMRT gamma 3%/3mm result: 520 pass out of 560 points. Pass rate?
qa.e: 520/560 √ó 100 = 92.9%. Below TG-218 universal tolerance of 95% ‚Äî investigation required but above 90% action limit.
Monthly verification of couch translational (¬± 2 mm) and rotational (¬± 1¬∞) accuracy.

qa.q: Baseline shift in output constancy indicates?
qa.e: Gradual output trends may indicate target/waveguide aging, magnetron changes, or chamber degradation. Investigate before it exceeds tolerance.
Second-check calculation using independent algorithm or hand calculation. Catches TPS input and modelling errors.

equip.e: Highest clinical dose rate ‚Äî enables fast SRS/SBRT treatments.
Enclosed O-ring gantry: faster rotation but limits non-coplanar access.
Only 6 FFF photons. No electron beams, no energy selection.
Varian provides a pre-validated 'golden' beam dataset. Limited user tuning.
Central 20 pairs at 5 mm, outer 20 pairs at 10 mm.
32 central pairs at 2.5 mm ‚Äî superior conformity for small SRS targets.
4√ó faster than TrueBeam (1 RPM). Rapid VMAT but coplanar only.
Dual-layer SX2 MLC stacks two offset banks, reducing leakage vs single-layer.
Single-layer tungsten. Higher leakage than SX2 but within tolerance.
Manages patient data, scheduling, and record & verify.
Bore geometry limits field size. Insufficient for some large palliative fields.
C-arm allows full 40 √ó 40 ‚Äî handles all standard and large-field techniques.
AI auto-contouring for online adaptive replanning, built on Halcyon hardware.
Commonly used for breast and abdominal SBRT.
O-ring design prevents couch kicks ‚Äî unsuitable for intracranial SRS.

equip.q: Elekta Versa HD max dose rate (FFF)?
equip.e: Elekta Versa HD offers FFF at 6 and 10 MV. 10 FFF reaches 2200 MU/min.
Agility has 160 leaves all at 5 mm width ‚Äî uniform resolution across the full 40 cm field.
Standing or travelling wave accelerating structure uses RF (typically 3 GHz) to push electrons to MeV energies.
Magnetrons are cheaper (lower energy linacs). Klystrons amplify an RF signal ‚Äî used in high-energy machines needing stable output.
270¬∞ achromatic bending magnets redirect and energy-select the electron beam in compact linac heads.
High-Z tungsten maximises bremsstrahlung yield. Also has a high melting point for thermal handling.
Conical metal filter preferentially attenuates the central beam peak to produce a flat dose profile.
Dual sealed ion chambers continuously monitor output (MU) and beam symmetry/flatness during treatment. Beam interlocks if out of tolerance.
a-Si flat panel with Gd‚ÇÇO‚ÇÇS scintillator converts MV X-rays to visible light then to electrical signal for portal imaging.
Varian's implementation of VMAT ‚Äî continuous gantry rotation with variable MLC, dose rate, and gantry speed.

equip.a: Helical fan beam with binary MLC
c: Helical fan beam with binary MLC
equip.e: Accuray TomoTherapy delivers IMRT via a rotating fan beam and binary (open/closed) MLC in a helical pattern, like a CT scanner.
kV CBCT delivers non-trivial imaging dose per fraction. Must be justified and included in cumulative dose assessment.
Systems like AlignRT/IDENTIFY project and track the patient surface optically ‚Äî enables markerless setup and intra-fraction monitoring.
Electron cones/applicators are attached to the linac head to define the treatment field and reduce scatter contamination.
Six Degrees of Freedom: lateral, longitudinal, vertical shifts plus pitch, roll, yaw rotations for precise patient repositioning.

eclipse.e: Linear Boltzmann Transport Equation ‚Äî deterministic solver for photon and electron transport in heterogeneous media.
AAA uses 1D density scaling ‚Äî poor electron transport at tissue-lung interfaces.
Dose-to-medium is physically correct; dose-to-water allows comparison with older algorithms.

eclipse.q: D_m vs D_w: biggest difference in?
eclipse.e: Bone has very different stopping power ratios. D_m and D_w converge in soft tissue.
Must be reduced to ‚â§ 2 mm for SBRT and ‚â§ 1 mm for SRS.
Dynamic sliding windows with known gap widths. Extrapolate dose to zero gap = DLG.
Automatically reduces dose to all non-target tissue. Use it in every optimisation.
Ensures minimum CTV dose ‚â• 95% for 90% of patients. Œ£ = systematic, œÉ = random error SD.
Jaws follow MLC aperture dynamically. Enable for SBRT to improve OAR sparing.
Lower = more uniform dose. Some inhomogeneity acceptable in SRT.
Continuous rotation with simultaneous modulation. Typically 2-3 min vs 10-15 for step-and-shoot.
Site-specific HU-to-density table. Wrong curve = systematic dose errors in every plan.
Overestimate density ‚Üí underestimate dose. Most critical in lung and bone.
Donut around PTV for optimisation. Tighter ring = steeper falloff.
High modulation (>3-4√ó) = complex MLC motion, higher delivery uncertainty.
PO optimises simultaneously over MLC, gantry speed, and dose rate for arc-based IMRT/VMAT plans.

eclipse.a: Coarse grid far, fine grid near target
c: Coarse grid far, fine grid near target
eclipse.e: Speeds up optimisation by using fine grids near targets/OARs and coarser grids elsewhere.
Bolus draws the dmax buildup region closer to the skin surface. Must be placed physically on the patient too.
CTV‚ÜíPTV margins can be uniform (isotropic) or direction-specific (anisotropic) to account for different error sources.

eclipse.a: Deformable registration needed for different CTs
c: Cannot sum plans at all in Eclipse
Deformable registration needed for different CTs
Limited to combining only two plans
Only available for photon beam plans
eclipse.e: Summing plans on different CT datasets requires deformable image registration (DIR) to map dose between anatomies.

eclipse.a: Cumulative: volume‚â•dose; Differential: volume at dose
c: Cumulative: volume‚â•dose; Differential: volume at dose
Differential DVH is always preferred clinically
Cumulative DVH is never used in practice
eclipse.e: Cumulative DVH (standard clinical use) shows what percentage of structure receives at least a given dose.
ICRU concept: OAR + margin for geometric uncertainty, analogous to CTV‚ÜíPTV for targets.
ICRU 83 recommends reporting D50% (near-median) as the primary dose descriptor for IMRT plans.
Without heterogeneity corrections, lung tumour doses can be overestimated by 10-20%. AcurosXB handles this better than AAA.
HI = (72-65)/70 = 7/70 = 0.10. Lower values indicate more homogeneous dose. Typical VMAT plans achieve 0.05-0.15.

eclipse.a: Reduce T&G effect, improve OAR sparing
c: Reduce T&G effect, improve OAR sparing
eclipse.e: Rotating the collimator can align MLC travel direction to better spare critical structures and reduce interleaf leakage patterns.

c: 95% of dose delivered to 95% of OAR
eclipse.e: Standard target coverage constraint: at least 95% of the PTV should receive 95% of the prescription dose.

eclipse.a: Accounts for couch attenuation in dose calc
c: Accounts for couch attenuation in dose calc
eclipse.e: Treatment couch structures model beam attenuation through the couch (~2-6% for posterior beams), improving dose accuracy.

eclipse.q: VMAT dual arc advantage over single arc?
eclipse.e: Two arcs provide more modulation degrees of freedom, especially for complex targets like H&N with many OAR constraints.
Modulation Complexity Score (MCS), aperture irregularity, and MU/cGy ratio help predict deliverability and QA pass rates.

dosimetry.e: Tissue-Phantom Ratio at 20 and 10 cm depth. Used to select k_Q.
Absorbed dose to water calibration coefficient, traceable to a primary standards lab.
Measure at V and V/2 to quantify incomplete ion collection. Critical for FFF.
Air density varies with T and P. Must measure at time of calibration.
Combined standard uncertainty of ~1.5% (1œÉ). The floor of our accuracy.
South Africa follows IAEA TRS-398. TG-51 is the North American equivalent.
Both N_D,w-based. TRS-398 uses TPR‚ÇÇ‚ÇÄ,‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ; TG-51 uses %dd(10)x.
Tabulated per chamber model and beam quality. Corrects relative to Co-60 calibration.
Universal reference condition at SSD 100 cm or SAD 100 cm.
Deep enough to avoid contaminant electrons.
Reverse polarity and average. Corrects for stem and cable irradiation effects.

dosimetry.q: Why k_s matters more for FFF?
dosimetry.e: More dose per pulse ‚Üí more recombination ‚Üí larger correction.
Standard reference chamber for absolute dosimetry. Too large for small fields (< 4√ó4 cm¬≤) ‚Äî use smaller detectors.
Thin entrance window minimises perturbation in electron beams. Required for electron energies where cylindrical chambers have too much perturbation.

dosimetry.q: CALC: Chamber reading 25.6 nC, N_D,w = 4.88 cGy/nC, k_Q = 0.993, k_TP = 1.005, k_s = 1.003, k_pol = 1.001. Dose?

dosimetry.e: High-sensitivity electrometer measures picocoulomb-level charges from ionisation chambers with high precision.

dosimetry.a: Calibrate field chamber against reference chamber
c: Calibrate field chamber against reference chamber
dosimetry.e: A field chamber used daily is cross-calibrated against the primary reference chamber to establish its own calibration coefficient.
Percentage Depth Dose varies with all four parameters. Larger fields and higher energies shift dmax deeper.
Tissue-Maximum Ratio is defined at SAD setup and doesn't depend on SSD ‚Äî preferred for isocentric calculations.

dosimetry.a: Dose ratio: field size vs 10√ó10 ref
c: Dose ratio: field size vs 10√ó10 ref
dosimetry.e: Total scatter factor S_cp = S_c √ó S_p combines collimator scatter (S_c) and phantom scatter (S_p) relative to reference field.
Radiochromic film (EBT3/EBT-XD) provides sub-mm spatial resolution 2D dose distributions. Needs careful calibration and handling.
Alanine pellets read by EPR spectroscopy ‚Äî used by IAEA/NPL for postal dose audit programs. Very stable, near water-equivalent.
Detectors (diodes, MOSFETs, OSLDs) placed on or in the patient measure actual delivered dose as an independent safety check.

dosimetry.q: Diode vs ion chamber for relative dosimetry?
dosimetry.a: Diode has higher sensitivity per volume
c: Diode has higher sensitivity per volume
dosimetry.e: Silicon diodes are ~18,000√ó more sensitive per unit volume than air ‚Äî ideal for relative measurements in small volumes.
3D water tank with motorised detector scanning provides beam data for TPS commissioning: depth doses, cross-profiles, and output factors.
k_TP = (297.15/295.15) √ó (101.33/100.5) = 1.00678 √ó 1.00826 ‚âà 1.014. Warmer air is less dense ‚Üí larger correction.

dosimetry.q: Effective point of measurement for cylindrical chamber?
dosimetry.e: The effective point of measurement is shifted 0.6 times the cavity radius toward the source to account for the gradient effect.

nucmed.e: Ideal for imaging: long enough for prep and scanning, short enough for low patient dose.
Optimal for NaI(Tl) detection ‚Äî good tissue penetration with efficient collimation.
Positron + electron ‚Üí two 511 keV photons at 180¬∞ ‚Äî basis of PET coincidence detection.
Long enough for synthesis, transport, uptake and scanning. Most widely used PET tracer.
Used for thyroid ablation therapy. Long half-life requires radiation protection precautions.
Also emits beta particles (therapeutic). The 364 keV gamma enables post-therapy imaging.
Most common general-purpose. Pinhole for thyroid; fan beam for brain SPECT.
Camera rotates to acquire projections, reconstructed into 3D.
Limited by positron range, photon non-collinearity, and crystal size.
'Milked' daily. Mo-99 (66h) decays to Tc-99m on an alumina column.
Fast timing, high light output, good stopping power for 511 keV.
Thallium-doped sodium iodide: excellent light yield at 140 keV.
Tc-99m-labelled RBCs imaged through cardiac cycle to calculate LVEF.
Generator-produced. Enables PET without a cyclotron ‚Äî used for PSMA and DOTATATE.
Lutathera (DOTATATE) and Pluvicto (PSMA) ‚Äî landmark theranostic treatments.

nucmed.a: Same molecule for diagnosis and therapy
c: Same molecule for diagnosis and therapy
nucmed.e: Pair diagnostic isotope (e.g., Ga-68) with therapeutic isotope (e.g., Lu-177) on the same targeting molecule. See-then-treat paradigm.
SUV normalises tracer uptake by injected activity and body weight. SUV > 2.5 often suggests malignancy for FDG-PET.
TOF localises the annihilation event along the LOR using timing differences, improving effective sensitivity and SNR.
Radium-223 (Xofigo) is a calcium-mimetic alpha emitter that incorporates into bone remodelling sites ‚Äî treats castration-resistant prostate cancer bone mets.

nucmed.q: Gamma camera energy window for Tc-99m?
nucmed.e: Photopeak window centered at 140 keV captures primary photons while rejecting scatter.
Cadmium Zinc Telluride (CZT) is a semiconductor ‚Äî direct conversion with superior energy resolution (~5% vs 10% for NaI). Used in cardiac SPECT.
Y-90 microspheres (SIR-Spheres/TheraSphere) are injected into hepatic artery to deliver localised beta radiation to liver tumours.
Well-type ionisation chamber calibrated in Bq/MBq to assay radiopharmaceutical activity before patient administration.

nucmed.q: CALC: Tc-99m initial activity 800 MBq. Activity after 12 hours?
nucmed.e: 12 hours = 2 half-lives (T¬Ω = 6.01 hr). A = 800 √ó (¬Ω)¬≤ = 800/4 = 200 MBq.
I-123/I-131 MIBG (meta-iodobenzylguanidine) is taken up by adrenergic tissue ‚Äî images and treats neuroblastoma and phaeochromocytoma.
PET/CT uses the CT data to generate attenuation correction factors for each LOR, improving quantitative accuracy.
TEW uses two narrow windows flanking the photopeak to estimate scatter contribution within the main window.
NaI(Tl) probe counts over thyroid vs standard to determine fractional uptake ‚Äî guides I-131 therapy dosing.

nucmed.a: Larger ring = less sensitivity, fits larger patients
c: No effect on imaging performance at all
Larger ring = less sensitivity, fits larger patients
Smaller ring is always clinically better
Ring size only affects spatial resolution
nucmed.e: Solid angle subtended by detectors decreases with larger rings (lower geometric efficiency), but larger bores accommodate bigger patients.

nucmed.q: CALC: I-131 treatment activity for thyroid ablation (typical)?
nucmed.e: Ablation of thyroid remnants after surgery typically uses 1.1-3.7 GBq. Higher activities for metastatic disease.

diag.e: Mo produces 17-20 keV characteristic X-rays optimal for breast contrast.
Average dose in a standard phantom for a single rotation. Measured in mGy.

diag.q: CT dose metric for exam length?
diag.e: Dose-Length Product = CTDIvol √ó scan length (mGy¬∑cm).
Uses tissue weighting factors to estimate stochastic risk from partial-body exposure.
DAP (Gy¬∑cm¬≤) captures both dose intensity and beam area.
One of the lowest medical exposures. The reference unit for public communication.
Equivalent to ~400-500 chest X-rays. Justification and optimisation essential.
Water = 0 by definition. Air = -1000. Dense bone ~+1000.
HU = 1000 √ó (Œº_tissue - Œº_water) / Œº_water.
X-rays from deeper in the anode are more attenuated ‚Üí intensity variation.
Terminates exposure when detector receives sufficient signal for diagnostic quality.
Higher kVp = more penetrating beam, lower contrast. Trade-off with patient dose.
Doubling mAs doubles dose and halves quantum noise.
CR uses photostimulable phosphor plates; DR uses amorphous silicon or selenium flat panels.
Maximum spatial frequency a detector can resolve = 1/(2 √ó pixel pitch).
DQE measures how efficiently a detector converts incident X-ray quanta to useful signal. Higher DQE = better image quality per dose.
FBP applies a ramp filter before back-projecting to remove blurring. Iterative reconstruction is increasingly replacing FBP.

diag.a: Lower noise at same dose (dose saving)
c: Lower noise at same dose (dose saving)
diag.e: Iterative methods model noise and physics more accurately, enabling 20-40% dose reduction while maintaining image quality.
Polychromatic beam loses low-energy photons passing through dense structures, shifting the mean energy upward and causing cupping/streak artefacts.
Water should read 0 ¬± 4 HU. Deviations indicate calibration issues affecting dose calculations when CT is used for RT planning.
Lead strips absorb scatter photons (typically moving at oblique angles) while transmitting primary photons, improving contrast.

diag.a: Height of lead strips / gap between strips
c: Height of lead strips / gap between strips
diag.e: Higher grid ratios (e.g., 12:1) absorb more scatter but require higher exposure. Common values: 8:1 to 12:1.
Compression reduces breast thickness to 4-6 cm, improving contrast, reducing dose, and separating overlapping structures.
Two energy datasets enable material characterisation (e.g., iodine mapping, uric acid detection) and virtual non-contrast images.
Modulation Transfer Function quantifies how well a system preserves contrast at different spatial frequencies. MTF=1 at zero frequency.
Heat generated in the anode limits continuous use. Rotating anodes dissipate heat more effectively than stationary.

diag.q: CALC: Patient effective dose from CT scan. DLP=600 mGy¬∑cm, k-factor=0.015 mSv/(mGy¬∑cm). Effective dose?
diag.e: E = DLP √ó k = 600 √ó 0.015 = 9 mSv. k-factors are region-specific (abdomen ‚âà 0.015, head ‚âà 0.0021).
Window Width controls contrast range; Window Level (centre) controls brightness. Lung window: WW=1500, WL=-600. Bone: WW=2000, WL=300.
Smaller focal spot = sharper image but lower tube loading capacity. Mammography uses 0.1-0.3 mm focal spots.
Pitch > 1: gaps between rotations (faster, lower dose). Pitch < 1: overlapping data (slower, higher dose, better quality).

radiobio.e: Œ± = single-hit kills (linear), Œ≤ = two-hit kills (quadratic). Foundation of fractionation theory.
Late tissues (spinal cord, lung) are more sensitive to fraction size ‚Äî the basis for conventional 2 Gy fractionation.
Fast-dividing tissues (tumours, skin, mucosa) are less sensitive to fraction size changes.
The biological rationale for fractionation ‚Äî each R favours tumour kill over normal tissue damage.
Ratio of doses needed for same effect in hypoxic vs oxygenated cells.
Hypoxic cells need 2.5-3√ó more dose. Reoxygenation between fractions helps overcome this.
Compares biological effect of different radiation types relative to a reference (250 kVp X-rays).
Historical standard. RBE = Dose(reference) / Dose(test) for same biological effect.
Energy deposited per unit path length (keV/Œºm). Higher LET = more biological damage per track.
Alphas deposit ~100 keV/Œºm vs ~0.2 keV/Œºm for photons. Dense ionisation = more lethal.
Probability of eradicating all clonogenic tumour cells. Sigmoid function of dose.
Probability of causing a specific complication. Also a sigmoid function of dose.
Wider separation = better. RT aims to maximise TCP while keeping NTCP acceptably low.
Biologically Effective Dose. Allows comparison of different fractionation schedules.
Unusually low ‚Äî prostate tumours behave like late-responding tissue. Supports hypofractionation.
Mitosis and late G2 have condensed chromosomes and reduced repair capacity ‚Äî most vulnerable to radiation damage.
Late S phase has active homologous recombination repair and sister chromatids available as templates.

radiobio.a: O‚ÇÇ makes DNA damage permanent (fixes radicals)
c: O‚ÇÇ prevents all radiation DNA damage
O‚ÇÇ makes DNA damage permanent (fixes radicals)
O‚ÇÇ actively repairs damaged DNA strands
radiobio.e: Oxygen reacts with radiation-produced free radicals on DNA, making the damage irreparable. Without O‚ÇÇ, the radical can be chemically restored.
After ~28 days, surviving tumour clonogens proliferate faster. This is why treatment breaks and prolongation are detrimental.
Equivalent Dose in 2 Gy fractions. Converts any schedule to its equivalent in standard 2 Gy fractions for comparison.

radiobio.q: CALC: BED for 50 Gy in 5 fx, Œ±/Œ≤ = 10 Gy?
radiobio.e: d = 50/5 = 10 Gy per fraction. BED = nd(1 + d/(Œ±/Œ≤)) = 50 √ó (1 + 10/10) = 50 √ó 2 = 100 Gy‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ.
Most sublethal damage is repaired within 1-2 hours. This is why fractions are spaced ‚â•6 hours apart (‚â•3 half-times).

radiobio.a: Unirradiated cells near irradiated cells show damage
c: Unirradiated cells near irradiated cells show damage
Only directly hit cells are affected
radiobio.e: Irradiated cells release signalling molecules that can induce DNA damage, apoptosis, or genomic instability in neighbouring unirradiated cells.
Rare phenomenon where localised radiation triggers immune response causing regression of metastases outside the treatment field.
DSBs are the most lethal form of DNA damage. A single unrepaired DSB can kill a cell. Repaired by NHEJ or HR.
NHEJ directly ligates broken DNA ends without a template ‚Äî fast but error-prone. Dominant repair pathway in mammalian cells.
Hypoxic tumour cells require 2.5-3√ó higher dose for equivalent kill. Strategies: fractionation (reoxygenation), hypoxic sensitisers, carbogen breathing.

radiobio.q: CALC: EQD2 for 30 Gy / 10 fx, Œ±/Œ≤ = 3 Gy?

radiobio.e: Cisplatin inhibits DNA repair and synergises with radiation. Standard for H&N, cervix, lung chemoradiation.
Amifostine (WR-2721) is a thiol compound that scavenges free radicals, selectively protecting normal tissues over tumours.

radprot.e: The overarching principle: minimise dose consistent with practical constraints.
Minimise time, maximise distance (inverse square), interpose shielding.
Dose ‚àù 1/r¬≤. Double the distance = quarter the dose. The most powerful protection tool.
High-Z materials attenuate MV beams. Concrete is most common; lead for space-constrained areas.
Thickness of material to reduce beam intensity by 50%. Depends on energy and material.
Reduces beam to 10%. TVL ‚âà 3.32 √ó HVL.
One TVL = factor of 10 reduction. Two TVLs = factor of 100, etc.
NCRP 151 covers structural shielding design for megavoltage RT facilities.
Total dose output at 1 m from source per week. Key input for shielding calculations.
Fraction of time beam is directed at that wall. ¬º assumes 4 cardinal gantry angles.

radprot.q: Occupancy factor (T) for office next door?
radprot.e: T=1 for areas with permanent occupants. Lower for corridors (¬º), toilets (1/16).
Photonuclear threshold ~8-10 MV. Requires additional shielding (polyethylene, borated materials).
IC survey meters give accurate dose rate readings across the energy range.
TLD (thermoluminescence) and OSL (optically stimulated luminescence) are standard personal monitors.
Multiple scattering events along the maze attenuate dose to manageable levels at the entrance.
Secondary barriers are thinner than primary because they shield against lower-energy scatter and head leakage (~0.1% of primary).
IEC standard: leakage radiation at 1 m from source must not exceed 0.1% of the maximum dose rate of the useful beam.
E = Œ£ w_T √ó H_T. Tissue weighting factors sum to 1.0 and reflect relative radiation sensitivity of different organs.
H_T = Œ£ w_R √ó D_T,R. w_R = 1 for photons/electrons, 20 for alpha particles, 2.5-21 for neutrons (energy-dependent).
Low-LET radiations (photons, electrons) have w_R = 1. The absorbed dose in Gy equals equivalent dose in Sv.
High-LET alpha particles cause dense ionisation tracks ‚Äî 20√ó more biologically damaging per unit dose than photons.

radprot.q: Radiation area monitoring: passive vs active?
radprot.e: Passive dosimeters integrate dose over time. Active monitors give real-time readings with alarms for dose rate thresholds.
International radiation trefoil symbol, radiation type, dose rate information, and controlled access measures are required.
Stuck HDR source: evacuate patient area, maximise distance, use emergency container if available, contact physicist and RPO immediately.

radprot.q: CALC: Annual dose to office (100% occupancy). Dose rate at wall = 0.5 ¬µSv/hr. Hours/year = 2000. Annual dose?
radprot.e: D = 0.5 ¬µSv/hr √ó 2000 hr = 1000 ¬µSv = 1.0 mSv. At the public limit ‚Äî shielding is just adequate.
Hydrogen-rich materials (poly) thermalise fast neutrons. Boron-10 then captures thermal neutrons via ¬π‚Å∞B(n,Œ±)‚Å∑Li reaction.

radprot.q: Ozone production concern in linac bunkers?
radprot.a: Ventilation must clear O‚ÇÉ between treatments
c: O‚ÇÉ is not produced by linacs
Ventilation must clear O‚ÇÉ between treatments
radprot.e: UV and ionising radiation produces ozone (O‚ÇÉ) from air. NCRP 151 recommends ventilation providing 6-10 air changes per hour.

radprot.q: CALC: Need to reduce 50 mSv/hr to 0.05 mSv/hr. Transmission = ?
radprot.e: T = 0.05/50 = 0.001 = 10‚Åª¬≥. Need 3 TVLs of shielding. TVL‚ÇÅ may differ from TVL_eq for the material.

radprot.a: Direct-shielded door is heavier but saves space
c: Direct-shielded door is heavier but saves space
radprot.e: Mazeless designs use massive shielded doors (several tonnes) ‚Äî saves floor space but requires motorised door systems.

radprot.a: Terminates beam if area dose rate exceeded
c: Terminates beam if area dose rate exceeded
radprot.e: Area radiation monitors with IDR interlocks automatically stop beam delivery if dose rate outside the bunker exceeds preset thresholds.

regs.q: Occupational dose/yr (SA)?
regs.e: ICRP/SA limit. Max 50 in any single year, 100 over 5 consecutive years.

regs.q: Controlled area limit?
regs.e: Areas requiring access control and monitoring for radiation workers.

regs.q: Uncontrolled area limit?
regs.e: Public areas ‚Äî corridors, waiting rooms, offices. Same as public dose limit.

regs.q: SASQART published by?
regs.e: South African Standards for Quality Assurance in Radiotherapy ‚Äî the national QA guideline.

regs.q: SA radiation legislation?
regs.e: Act 15 of 1973, Group IV hazardous substances. Governs all non-nuclear radiation use.

regs.q: Pregnant worker limit?
regs.e: For remainder of pregnancy once declared. Protects the embryo/fetus.

regs.q: SSDL stands for?
regs.e: Provides traceable calibrations for clinical dosimeters in SA.

regs.q: Professional registration body?
regs.e: Health Professions Council of SA ‚Äî registers medical physicists and other health professionals.

regs.q: Equipment licensing body?
regs.e: SA Health Products Regulatory Authority ‚Äî licenses all radiation-emitting equipment.

regs.q: 5-year cumulative dose limit?
regs.e: Ensures average ‚â§ 20 mSv/yr even if single years exceed it.

regs.q: Max dose in any single year?
regs.e: Flexibility clause: up to 50 mSv in one year if 5-year average stays ‚â§ 20 mSv.

regs.q: Public annual dose limit?
regs.e: ICRP recommended and adopted in SA. Excludes medical and natural background.

regs.q: HPCSA registration category for medical physicists?
regs.e: HPCSA registers medical physicists under the Professional Board for Radiography and Clinical Technology, with subspecialties in diagnostic or therapeutic physics.

regs.q: CEU points required per HPCSA cycle?
regs.e: HPCSA requires 30 Continuing Education Units per cycle for medical physicists. At least 5 must be in ethics, human rights, or medical law.

regs.q: HPCSA CEU cycle length?
regs.e: The HPCSA CPD cycle runs for 12 months. Practitioners must accumulate the required CEUs within each annual cycle.

regs.q: Minimum ethics CEUs per HPCSA cycle?
regs.e: HPCSA mandates at least 5 CEUs in ethics, human rights, or medical law per cycle to maintain registration.

regs.q: SAHPRA replaced which body?
regs.e: SAHPRA (South African Health Products Regulatory Authority) replaced the MCC in 2018, taking over regulation of medicines, medical devices, and radiation-emitting equipment.

regs.q: SAHPRA regulates radiation equipment under which Act?
regs.e: SAHPRA regulates Group III and IV hazardous substances under the Hazardous Substances Act. Group IV covers radioactive materials and radiation-generating equipment.

regs.q: Group IV hazardous substances include?
regs.e: Group IV of the Hazardous Substances Act specifically covers radioactive materials, radiation-generating equipment, and electronic products emitting radiation.

regs.q: NNR regulates which facilities?
regs.e: The National Nuclear Regulator (NNR) regulates nuclear installations (reactors, enrichment plants) and nuclear vessels under the National Nuclear Regulator Act (Act 47 of 1999).

regs.q: Who issues a licence for a new linac installation?
regs.e: SAHPRA's Radiation Control Directorate issues licences for radiation-emitting equipment including linacs, under the Hazardous Substances Act.

regs.q: ICRP 103 tissue weighting factor for gonads?
regs.e: ICRP 103 reduced the gonad weighting factor from 0.20 (ICRP 60) to 0.08, reflecting updated evidence on hereditary risk.

regs.q: ICRP 103 tissue weighting factor for breast?
regs.e: ICRP 103 increased breast weighting from 0.05 to 0.12, recognising higher radiation-induced cancer risk in breast tissue.

regs.q: CALC: Worker receives 15 mSv in year 1 and 18 mSv in year 2. Max allowed in year 3 to stay within 5-year limit?
regs.e: The 5-year limit is 100 mSv, and the single-year cap is 50 mSv. After 33 mSv in 2 years, 67 mSv remains over 3 years, but the annual cap of 50 mSv applies.

regs.q: CALC: How many TVLs to reduce dose rate from 40 mSv/hr to 0.04 mSv/hr?
regs.e: 40 / 0.04 = 1000 = 10¬≥, so 3 TVLs are needed. Each TVL reduces intensity by a factor of 10.

regs.q: CALC: Source at 1 m gives 8 mSv/hr. Dose rate at 4 m?
regs.e: Inverse square law: 8 √ó (1/4)¬≤ = 8 √ó 1/16 = 0.5 mSv/hr. Distance is the most effective protection tool.

regs.q: ICRP 103 annual eye lens dose limit for workers?
regs.e: ICRP revised the lens limit from 150 mSv to 20 mSv/year (averaged over 5 years, max 50 in a single year) based on cataract data.

regs.q: Annual extremity dose limit for workers?
regs.e: Hands, feet, and skin of extremities have a higher limit of 500 mSv/year because of their lower radiation sensitivity.

regs.q: Radiation Protection Officer (RPO) must be appointed when?
c: Only at facilities with sealed sources
regs.e: SA regulations require every facility holding a radiation licence to appoint a qualified RPO responsible for the radiation protection programme.

regs.q: Key RPO responsibility?
regs.e: The RPO oversees personal dosimetry, area monitoring, waste management, incident reporting, and ensures all licence conditions are met.

regs.q: Personal dosimetry monitoring frequency in SA?
regs.e: Personal dosimeters (TLD/OSL) are exchanged and read monthly in SA. This allows timely detection of elevated exposures.

regs.q: Investigation level for personal dosimetry in SA?
regs.e: Doses exceeding approximately 1 mSv per monitoring period trigger an investigation to identify causes and implement corrective actions.

regs.q: CALC: Pregnant worker declared at 8 weeks. Remaining pregnancy ~32 weeks. Max dose rate to abdomen?
regs.e: Limit is 2 mSv to lower abdomen for remainder of pregnancy. 2 mSv / 32 weeks = 0.0625 mSv/week.

regs.q: IAEA BSS document number?
regs.e: The IAEA General Safety Requirements Part 3 (GSR Part 3, 2014) replaced Safety Series 115 as the international Basic Safety Standards for radiation protection.

regs.q: ICRP 105 covers?
regs.e: ICRP Publication 105 provides guidance on radiation protection specific to medical exposures, including justification and optimisation for patients.

regs.q: Three principles of ICRP radiation protection system?
regs.e: ICRP 103 establishes justification (net benefit), optimisation (ALARA), and dose limitation (for workers/public, not patients) as the three pillars.

regs.q: Dose limits apply to which exposure category?
regs.e: ICRP dose limits apply to planned occupational and public exposures. Medical patient exposures are governed by justification and optimisation, not dose limits.

regs.q: CALC: Shielding reduces dose rate from 200 mSv/hr to 0.2 mSv/hr. How many HVLs?
regs.e: 200/0.2 = 1000. Since 2^n = 1000, n = log‚ÇÇ(1000) ‚âà 10 HVLs. Alternatively, 3 TVLs = 3 √ó 3.32 HVLs ‚âà 10 HVLs.

regs.q: Incident reporting timeframe for overexposure in SA?
regs.e: Significant radiation incidents must be reported to SAHPRA within 24 hours. A detailed investigation report follows within a specified timeframe.

regs.q: What triggers a radiation incident investigation?
regs.a: Dose exceeding prescribed limits or unintended exposure
c: Dose exceeding prescribed limits or unintended exposure
regs.e: Incidents include overexposures to workers/public, misadministrations to patients, loss of sources, and any unplanned or unintended radiation exposure.

regs.q: Transport of radioactive materials is governed by?
regs.e: South Africa adopts the IAEA Regulations for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Material (SSR-6) for packaging, labelling, and transport requirements.

regs.q: Transport Index (TI) on a package indicates?
regs.a: Maximum dose rate at 1 m in mSv/hr √ó 100
c: Mass of radioactive contents in grams
Maximum dose rate at 1 m in mSv/hr √ó 100
Activity in multiples of exemption level
regs.e: The TI is determined from the maximum radiation level at 1 metre from the package surface, controlling vehicle loading and spacing.

regs.q: White-I transport label: max surface dose rate?
regs.e: Category I-White has the lowest surface dose rate limit (5 ¬µSv/hr) and a TI of 0. Yellow-II and Yellow-III allow progressively higher levels.

regs.q: Yellow-II transport label: max TI?
regs.e: Yellow-II packages have TI ‚â§ 1.0 and surface dose rate ‚â§ 0.5 mSv/hr. Yellow-III allows TI up to 10.

regs.q: CALC: Source with activity 400 MBq and dose rate constant Œì = 0.1 ¬µSv¬∑m¬≤/(MBq¬∑hr). Dose rate at 2 m?
regs.e: Dose rate = Œì √ó A / d¬≤ = 0.1 √ó 400 / 4 = 10 ¬µSv/hr. The dose rate constant relates activity to dose rate at unit distance.

regs.q: Record retention for personal dosimetry in SA?
regs.a: Until worker reaches age 75 or 30 years
c: Until worker reaches age 75 or 30 years
regs.e: SA regulations require dose records to be kept until the worker reaches 75 years of age or for 30 years after the last recorded dose, whichever is longer.

regs.q: Radiation equipment QC records must be kept for?
regs.a: Duration of equipment use plus 3 years
c: Duration of equipment use plus 3 years
regs.e: QC records should be retained for the operational life of the equipment plus an additional period (typically 3 years) to support audits and inspections.

regs.q: Environmental monitoring at a radiation facility includes?
regs.a: Area dose rate surveys and contamination checks
c: Area dose rate surveys and contamination checks
regs.e: Environmental monitoring involves regular area dose rate measurements, surface contamination monitoring (for unsealed sources), and air monitoring where applicable.

regs.q: CALC: Worker accumulates 18, 22, 15, 20 mSv over 4 years. Max allowed in year 5?
regs.e: 5-year limit is 100 mSv. Sum of 4 years = 75 mSv. Remaining = 25 mSv. Although 50 mSv is the annual cap, the 5-year constraint limits year 5 to 25 mSv.

regs.q: SA radiation facility must have which document?
regs.e: Every licensed facility must establish and maintain a documented RPP covering policies, procedures, responsibilities, and emergency arrangements.

regs.q: QMS requirement for radiation therapy in SA?
regs.e: SA regulations and SASQART require a documented QMS covering all aspects of radiation therapy from referral to treatment completion and follow-up.

regs.q: ICRP dose constraint concept means?
regs.e: Dose constraints are set below dose limits as a prospective tool to guide optimisation (ALARA). They are not limits but planning targets.

regs.q: CALC: Room requires 2.5 TVLs of lead shielding. TVL = 5.7 cm. Required thickness?
regs.e: Thickness = 2.5 √ó 5.7 cm = 14.25 cm. Each TVL reduces dose by a factor of 10, so 2.5 TVLs gives a factor of ~316.

regs.q: Authorisation to practice as medical physicist in SA requires?
regs.e: A medical physicist must hold HPCSA registration and work at a facility with a valid SAHPRA radiation licence. Both individual and institutional authorisation are required.

regs.q: Trainee medical physicist (registrar) supervision requirement?
regs.e: HPCSA requires registrars to work under the direct supervision of a registered medical physicist throughout their training period.

regs.q: HPCSA medical physics internship duration?
regs.e: The HPCSA-accredited medical physics internship (registrar training) is 2 years, during which candidates must complete clinical rotations and a logbook.

regs.q: CALC: Background dose rate is 0.1 ¬µSv/hr. Worker spends 2000 hr/yr in area with 5 ¬µSv/hr. Annual occupational dose?
regs.e: Occupational dose = (5 - 0.1) √ó 2000 = 4.9 √ó 2000 = 9800 ¬µSv = 9.8 mSv. Background is subtracted for occupational dose assessment.

regs.q: Patient dose reference levels (DRLs) are?
c: Strict upper dose limits for patients
regs.e: DRLs are set at the 75th percentile of facility doses for standard procedures. Exceeding them triggers investigation but is not a violation.

regs.q: Skin dose limit for workers (SA)?
regs.e: The annual equivalent dose limit for the skin is 500 mSv, averaged over any 1 cm¬≤ area, consistent with ICRP 103 recommendations.

regs.q: CALC: Ir-192 source, 370 GBq. Dose rate constant = 0.113 mSv¬∑m¬≤/(GBq¬∑hr). Dose rate at 0.5 m?
regs.e: Dose rate = 0.113 √ó 370 / (0.5)¬≤ = 41.81 / 0.25 = 167.2 mSv/hr. High dose rates demand strict time and distance controls.

regs.q: Sealed source leak test frequency?
regs.e: Sealed sources must undergo wipe tests at least every 6 months to detect any leakage of radioactive material, as required by SA licence conditions.

regs.q: Disposal of disused sealed sources in SA?
regs.e: Disused sealed sources must be returned to the supplier or transferred to NECSA (South African Nuclear Energy Corporation) for safe management and disposal.
